sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.title: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices | BVMS UI Automation
sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.keywords: Namespace Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.Devices Classes AddDeviceDialog<T> Base class for dialogs which appears during creation of a device. AddDeviceDialogConfig<T> Configuration properties for dialog which is used to add a new Device<T> . DeviceDialog<T> Base class for all dialogs which are related to devices. DeviceDialogConfig<T> Configuration properties for a dialog which is used to configure Device<T> . DeviceManager<T> A DeviceManager<T> handles how a device is added, modified and removed in the UI. Depending upon the type of a device some devices appear as own nodes in the DeviceTree and others only as a table in the right pane. Therefore very distinct UI approaches are necessary to access and manage these devices. DeviceManagerFacade DevicesPageObject Page Object for the DeviceTree and belonging pane at right side. EditDeviceDialog<T> Configuration properties for a dialog which is used to modify the settings of a Device<T> . PaneDeviceManager<T> A PaneDeviceManager<T> is used to manage Device<T> s which are not handled as a separate node in the DeviceTree. Instead they are handled at the right side of the ConfigClient by selecting their belonging DeviceType node in the DeviceTree (e.g. enterprise Server ). TreeDeviceManager<T> A TreeDeviceManager<T> handles how a Device<T> , which appears as own nodes in the DeviceTree, has to be managed. Usually it covers the calling of context sensitive menus and showing related dialog. Interfaces IDeviceManager IDevicesPageObject Contract to specify the interaction with the devices.

sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.title: Class DeviceManager<T> | BVMS UI Automation
sdk/Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.D.keywords: Class DeviceManager<T> A DeviceManager<T> handles how a device is added, modified and removed in the UI. Depending upon the type of a device some devices appear as own nodes in the DeviceTree and others only as a table in the right pane. Therefore very distinct UI approaches are necessary to access and manage these devices. Methods AddDevice(T) Adds a new device to the DeviceTree. Declaration public virtual void AddDevice(T device) Parameters Type Name Description T device The new device. wiki/basics/tools.html.title: Tools | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/basics/tools.html.keywords: Tools [[ TOC ]] Frequently used CLI commands CLI commands for compilation, unit testing, Paket , Git Benefits of Visual Studio Code How Visual Studio Code can be used to debug FAKE build scripts. Benefits of LINQPad How LINQPad can speed you up during development Frequently used CLI commands Hint: The following commands are supposed to be used inside a Git Bash or Developer Prompt for Visual Studio . Therefore they use forward slashes ( / ) or backward slashes ( \ ) for folder separation. So please use the right CLI environment to run the program. Recommendation: Use the Developer Prompt for Visual Studio for everything around compiling the codebase and the Git Bash for everything around versioning. Hint: All commands are treated as used from the project root folder (aka DevTree root folder). Compilation/Build msbuild .\src\Bvms.UiAutomation.sln /t:Restore msbuild .\src\Bvms.UiAutomation.sln Run unit tests Bash: ./packages/xunit.runner.console/tools/net472/xunit.console.exe ./src/ConfigClient.DomainModel/ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests/bin/Debug/ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests.dll ./packages/xunit.runner.console/tools/net472/xunit.console.exe ./src/UseCaseTests/UseCaseTests/bin/Debug/Bvms.UiAutomation.UseCaseTests.dll ./deploy/xunit.console.exe ./deploy/Bvms.UiAutomation.UseCaseTests.dll Command Prompt: .\packages\xunit.runner.console\tools\net472\xunit.console.exe .\src\ConfigClient.DomainModel\ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests\bin\Debug\Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.DomainModel.Tests.dll .\packages\xunit.runner.console\tools\net472\xunit.console.exe .\src\UseCaseTests\UseCaseTests\bin\Debug\Bvms.UiAutomation.UseCaseTests.dll Paket install or update dependencies (after modifying central paket.dependencies or project specific paket.reference ) .paket/paket.exe install .paket/paket.exe restore Git Hint: Some of the following Git commands make use of aliases. Ensure that your personal .gitconfig contains these aliases. You can read more about the default configuration in the Baseline chapter of the Installation Guideline . show the status git st switch to branch; Create new branch and switch to it git co <branch-name> git co -b <new-branch-name> merge or rebase content of other branch in current branch Important: Use always the --ff-only option for a merge to avoid a 2-way merge! git merge <other-branch-name> --ff-only git rebase <new-branch-name> synchronization between local and remote repository git fetch --all git push git pull --ff-only Benefits of Visual Studio Code Debugging FAKE scripts Debugging FAKE scripts without a proper tool set can be a time consuming and annoying task. But VSC can be used as real IDE with debugging capabilities. see also Debugging of FAKE 5 build scripts Download fake-dotnetcore-portable.zip (e.g. from https://github.com/fsharp/FAKE/releases ) Extract the archive to the portable apps folder (e.g. c:\_apps\Tools\fake-dotnetcore-portable ) Open Visual Studio Code Click in the sidebar Extensions and install the following extensions: C# Ionide-fsharp Ionide-FAKE Ionide-Paket Click in the sidebar Debug expand configurations-combobox and choose Add Configuration in the list select dotnet core paste this configuration block directly inside the square brackets of the configuration key { "name": Debug Fake Script, "type": coreclr, "request": launch, "program": c:\_apps\Tools\fake-dotnetcore-portable\fake.dll, "args": [run, nocache, fsiargs, debug:portable optimize-, build.fsx], "cwd": ${workspaceRoot}, "stopAtEntry": false, "console": internalConsole } save the launch.json configuration file set breakpoints where wanted select in the configurations-combobox the new configuration Debug Fake Script and run this configuration Benefits of LINQPad LINQPad is a small utility to interactively writing C# code without the need for a heavyweight IDE. It comes in different edition where also the free edition give some benefits. But only the higher versions are really useful. With LINQPad it is much more faster to interact with an application which needs to get UI Automation driven. The most important fact is the almost infinite small compilation and startup time. Here are the steps to connect to the ConfigClient : Start the ConfigClient Start LINQPad Under Language select C# Program Press F4 to open dialog Query Properties where you can adjust some properties On tab Additional References click button Add NuGet... In new opened dialog LINQPad NuGet Manager search for FlaUI.UIA3 and add the package with button Add to Query and close the dialog with button Close . this should also add the package _ FlaUI Core . If not, add the package like the first package. On tab Additional Namespace Imports add some default namespaces, like FlaUI.UIA3 , FlaUI.Core , FlaUI.Core.AutomationElements and close with OK Use the script below as a example to interact with the ConfigClient void Main() { var processName = "ConfigClient"; var process = Process.GetProcesses().FirstOrDefault(p => p.ProcessName.Equals(processName)); var app = Application.Attach(process); using (var automation = new UIA3Automation()) { var window = app.GetMainWindow(automation); var toolbar = window.FindFirstDescendant("MainMenu : Toolbar"); var children = toolbar.FindAllChildren(); foreach (var element in children) { Console.WriteLine("element: " + element.Name); if (element.Name == "System") { element.Click(); } } } }

wiki/basics/smm.html.title: Software Maintenance Manual | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/basics/smm.html.keywords: Software Maintenance Manual [[ TOC ]] Get the Sources To maintain also the DocFX assets it is necessary to establish an access to the related Github resource (see Access Github ). But it is not necessary if you don't like to do that. current URL: git@ssh.dev.azure.com:v3/pas4/Bvms.UiAutomation/Bvms.UiAutomation use option -recursive to clone the Git repository with sub modules see also Documentation Access Github Remark: Some of the following SSH assets are located in the .ssh folder of your home folder. Depending on where you have booted your machine this folder can be a different folder. So it is wise to mirror all SSH settings for the possible folders. Usually the home folder is one of these folders: c:\users\<account> u:\ To check where your current home folder is, run cd %homepath% in a prompt or paste %homepath% in the File Explorer address line. Provide the SSH certificates Create a key-pair for SSH (name it pas4 and pas4.pub ) Store these files in the .ssh folder Ask apm1grb to include the public key ( pas4.pub ) in the settings of the apm1grb.github.io project Hint: In case you are not that familiar with SSH you can get a valid key-pair which let you skip the creation steps. Create a server alias Open the .ssh folder in your home folder Open the config file and add the alias Host as-apm1grb HostName github.com User git IdentityFile ~/.ssh/pas4 IdentitiesOnly yes Check the connection run ssh -v as-apm1grb inside a bash; this should not throw errors Prerequisites Ignore specific exception types see also 7 Debugging Techniques you should know in C# .NET - 2. Breaking on Exceptions with or without source code Open tool window Exception Settings Navigate to node Common language Runtime Exceptions Add the following types of exceptions and adjust the conditions Type Condition Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.UiElementDisabledException Module Name Not Equal Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.dll Bvms.UiAutomation.SDK.Commons.NavigationException Module Name Not Equal Bvms.UiAutomation.SDK.Commons.dll Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.PrepareForWorkaroundException Module Name Not Equal Bvms.UiAutomation.ConfigClient.SDK.dll Environment Variables During unit testing the Configuration Client and the Operator Client needs to be started. Hence the unit test needs to know where the executables are located. In case they are not in the default location ( %ProgramFiles%\Bosch\.. ) or the credentials are not the default credentials (user is Admin and password is empty) it needs environment variables to overwrite the default settings. ConfigClient.Path , OperatorClient.Path folder where the ConfigClient.exe and OperatorClient.exe are located in ConfigClient.Args , OperatorClient.Args arguments to run the applications (e.g. -user "admin" -password "" ) For developing there are these ways to use these environment variables: Set the environment variables permanent Open dialog System Properties by running sysdm.cpl On tab Advanced click button Environment Variables... to open dialog Environment Variables Set up environment variables ConfigClient.Path , OperatorClient.Path , ConfigClient.Args , OperatorClient.Args as wanted Close dialogs with buttons OK After rebooting the machine these settings become valid Change environment variables temporary for an individual Visual Studio session Open the Developer Command Prompt for Visual Studio Set the environment variables as wanted, e.g. SET "ConfigClient.Path=C:\_projects\tfs\BVMS\Dev\bin\" SET "ConfigClient.Args=-user "admin" -password """ Start Visual Studio with devenv.exe Troubleshooting to verify the current value of an environment variable use ECHO %Variable% e.g. ECHO %ConfigClient.Path%

wiki/documentation/introduction.html.title: Introduction | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/documentation/introduction.html.keywords: Introduction [[_ TOC ]] Project documentation The project documentation for the BVMS UI Automation project is provided in a modern and state of the art model. It is based on these sources and perspectives: XML Comments this is the in-source XML-based code documentation with triple slash ( /// <summary>...</summary> ). Wiki which is hosted on Azure DevOps and based on MarkDown as the markup language and Git as the storage to interact with. It is located here: Wiki for BVMS UI Automation To keep the documentation parts as most as possible together we use the technique of Git sub-modules. Git sub-modules allow a Git ("main") repository to reference other ("sub") repositories. This gives the possibility to divide a project into several containers (e.g. because of different life cycle or usage needs) but bundle them together at a top level. In our concrete case we had to include two Git sub-modules BVMS UI Automation project Wiki this Wiki is a Git repository itself containing the MarkDown wiki pages DocFX based Online documentation GitHub Pages allow easily to host (static) web sites. These web sites have to be provided in a (dedicated) Git repository. So the output of DocFX (the static web sites) are committed to this Git repository and then pushed to the remote ( github.io ). Advice: To clone a Git repository together with its sub-modules use the option --recursive Documentation related workflows and guidelines Hints and Marker in the Source Code Often enough the developer is in hurry or in a spike mode where he wrote some unclean code lines which he later likes to adjust according the guidelines. Usually later he forget these necessary refactoring. To keep these construction zones on the desk it is wise to add some marker. Visual Studio offers such marker management with the Task List . Out of the box these markers are available: TODO , HACK , UNDONE and UnresolvedMergeConflict . With ReSharper we have another option, which allows us a better management of such markers and later an easier search. So we rely on the enhanced features of ReSharper for our marker management in the project. To have an access to our project specific markers it is necessary to add some additional markers. Open the ReSharper Settings Extensions > ReSharper > Options... Navigate to the setting for the To-do Explorer Tools > To-do Explorer Add the following additional items: Name Pattern Icon Selections Refactor (?<=\W|^)(?<TAG>REFACTOR)(\W|$)(.*) Warning Match in comments Hack (?<=\W|^)(?<TAG>HACK)(\W|$)(.*) Warning Match in comments Now you can use these new markers, e.g. // Refactor low: Method call without using the result? You should also add a hint how important that refactoring is. In this case it is low . Other priorities should be normal and high . To see the list of all markers open the window To-do Explorer Extensions > ReSharper > Tools > To-do Explorer see also: To-do Explorer Defining to-do patterns in ReSharper

wiki/patterns/template-method.html.title: Template Method | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/patterns/template-method.html.keywords: Template Method In class libraries with similar sibling classes the Template Method pattern is often seen. It allows to define in the parent class a common overall logic, where the individual steps could be adjusted regarding the needs in the derived classes. In the sample AddDevice is the Template Method which defines three steps. The middle step AddDeviceCore should allow the derived classes to implement its own logic. So this step can be defined as abstract or virtual to allow overriding. public class ParentClass { ... public void AddDevice(IDevice device) { DoSomethingBefore(); AddDeviceCore(device); DoSomethingAfter(); } protected abstract void AddDeviceCore(IDevice device); ... In the subclass now AddDeviceCore needs to be implemented. public class ParentClass { ... protected override void AddDeviceCore(IDevice device) { DecoderType.Value = device.DecoderName; ... } ... One other thing is to remark here. In the typical case, that only one step needs to be adjusted, the overridable method is named like the calling method with the suffix Core . Todo: more Details please

wiki/architecture/main-classes.html.title: Main Classes | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/architecture/main-classes.html.keywords: Main Classes [[ TOC ]] Devices Classes which are derived from IDevice are the assets which are managed from BVMS as devices in the Device Tree . Usually these devices are only a dumb representation of the BVMS managed devices in the meaning that they mostly consists of properties (e.g. device name, IP address,...). But in some cases they also own a behavior. A VRM for instance offers the possibility to add a pool via the method AddPool and a pool offers the possibility to add an encoder, VSG, SCSI via AddEncoder , AddVsg and AddScsi . All devices have one common property - that is the name of the device. Depending on the device type a device is listed in the DeviceTree on the left side or a pane on the right side. All devices are derived from IDevice and Device . The following picture gives an overview about the class hierarchy of devices. DeviceConfig The properties of a device are set during creation or update of a device. The necessary values are brought into the device via a belonging Config object. So each device Foo has a corresponding config object FooConfig . The config objects also form a hierarchy analogue to the hierarchy of the devices. And because they belong to devices they are implemented in a generic fashion: public class DeviceConfig<T> : IDeviceConfig where T : Device<T> This allows later inside the creation and update of a device an easy access to the properties of the provided configuration. The update of a device is done via this method: public virtual Device<T> UpdateDevice(DeviceConfig<T> config) So in the derived abstract VideoDeviceBase class we have this: Still not nice are the casts in the concrete config class and the cast to Device<T> . Maybe in future versions we find a way to eliminate this.) public override Device<T> UpdateDevice(DeviceConfig<T> config) { base.UpdateDevice(config); var cfg = (VideoDeviceBaseConfig<T>) config; IpAddress = cfg.IpAddress; Port = cfg.Port; ConnectionSecurity = cfg.ConnectionSecurity; Credentials = cfg.Credentials; return (T) this; DeviceManager To add and/or configure a device it is necessary to know how the device needs to be added. Some devices are added by using a context-sensitive menu at the device type node in the tree others are added via a button in the pane. A DeviceManager is responsible to handle that logic for a specific device. That means each device needs a corresponding and individual DeviceManager. All these DeviceManagers are subclasses of DeviceManager . AddDeviceDialog and EditDeviceDialog During adding a device, most devices need some details specified via a dialog. These dialogs are subclasses of a generic class: public abstract partial class AddDeviceDialog<T> : DeviceDialog<T> where T : Device<T> All devices with needs further details captured via a dialog, should derive from AddDeviceDialog<T> and implement the necessary individual logic. The same concerns the update case. There the base class is EditDeviceDialog<T> . In former versions the device itself was used as an input parameter a device related dialog. The properties of that device were used as the information how the content of a dialog (the UI elements) needs to be configured. Usually this maps indeed 1:1 (if you have a property of a device, you need a UI element to specify the property - e.g. device name via text field, TCP port via an integer spinner, and so on). But in some rare cases this dependency was not enough to manage the interaction with the dialog comprehensively. For an example, in dialog with capturing passwords a checkbox Show password is available. This information (to show the password or to hide it) is not part of the device. It is only a functionality inside the dialog for interacting with the password field in a specific manner. Hence we recognized that the dialog configuration needs to get separated from the device which needs to be configured. Therefore to each device configuring dialog AddFooDialog or EditFooDialog now a configuration class AddFooDialogConfig respectively EditFooDialogConfig belongs. These config classes are used in the dialog constructors to configure the UI elements of this dialog. Generic Dialog From the perspective of the PageObject pattern (see also Page Object Pattern ) and the best practices to return the subsequent PageObject (in case the dialog interaction will leave a PageObject ), it seemed to be a good idea to see a dialog as a fork - the OK button returns the PageObject for the confirmation case and the Cancel button returns the PageObject for the other one. The PageObject for the confirmation case can be the PageObject of the next "dialog page" in case of a Next - Next - Finish chain of a wizard. The PageObject for the canceling case is most often the PageObject of the preceding context - e.g. the PageObject of the application itself in case you jump directly back to the application. Both subsequent PageObject s are taken to design the interface of the GenericDialog as generic type parameters. public class GenericDialog<TConfirmationPo, TCancelPo> : DialogBase where TConfirmationPo : PageObject where TCancelPo : PageObject { In an instantiable derivation the constructor is used to inject the two logics (as delegates) to return the subsequent PageObject s for the confirmation and cancelation case. Therefore the expected subsequent PageObject can exactly be pre-formed and easily used during stepping through such PageObject -chains in automated UI tests. Today (2020/MAY) this design decision looks a little bit over-engineered with some too specific assumptions regarding the two cases and therefore two subsequent dialogs. In some rare cases a dialog has additional exits (and not only the assumpted two). Additionally during automated UI tests only one dedicated PageObject will be the expected one. So the second case will never happen in a concrete unit-test run. It must be clear which PageObject is the subsequent one, otherwise the automated UI test, would test in a too relaxed way. For these reasons it might be good enough to decrease the two type parameters to only one. So this unique PageObject is used as the one and only expected type parameter for the individual test case which is supposed to be realized.

wiki/documentation/docfx.html.title: DocFX | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/documentation/docfx.html.keywords: DocFX To process the content of these sources we use DocFX which is the successor of SHFB (Sandcastle Help File Builder). DocFX is platform-agnostic and runs perfectly also under .NET Core. DocFX creates static web-sites which can easily hosted somewhere. To update the documentation these steps are essential: Update the working tree to the latest stand of the Wiki content Extract the XML metadata of the source code (the XML comment) with DocFX Process the documentation input with DocFX to create static web sites as output Commit the output of DocFX to the "online documentation" repository connected to hoster Push this "online documentation" repository Follow the next sections to do that: Update the working tree Open Git Bash in/with sub-folder .../doc/wiki/ Run command git fetch to get the latest stand into your local repository Run command git status to ensure that nothing is uncommitted and the local and remote branch are at the latest stand the output should be something like: Your branch is up to date with 'origin/wikiMaster'. if not: stop further processing and first commit changes, rebase, ... Run command Git pull --ff-only to get the latest stand in your working tree Extract the XML metadata & process the documentation input For the following steps the DocFX toolset needs to be installed on your machine. Use Chocolatey with choco install docfx Open Command Prompt in/with DevTree root folder Run command docfx metadata doc\docfx.json -o doc to extract the metadata of the source code Run command docfx build .\doc\docfx.json to create the static web-sites Publish the updated documentation To have the updated documentation online available the repository containing the static web-pages must be updated and pushed. Open Git Bash in/with sub-folder .../doc/_site/ Run command git add . to stage all changes Run command git commit -am "update DocFX documentation" to commit the changes Run command git push to update the remote

wiki/documentation/xml-code-doc.html.title: XML code documentation comments | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/documentation/xml-code-doc.html.keywords: XML code documentation comments Typical phrases, templates and usages reference another type, method, property <see cref=""/> summary to describe the purpose of a dialog <summary>Dialog to add a new <see cref="..."/>.</summary> summary for a contract <summary>Contract to specify the interaction with the maps and logical structure.</summary> summary for a setter <summary>Sets the name for the <see cref="UserGroup"/>.</summary> returning itself for fluent interfaces <returns>The instance of the <see cref="..."/> itself to foster fluent interface style.</returns> template for boolean return values <value><c>true</c> if this instance is login attempt possible; otherwise, <c>false</c>.</value> where to use <seealso cref="..."/> (at the end) /// <summary>bla bla bla /// <para>foo foo foo.</para> /// <seealso cref="ThisClass.ThatMethod"/> /// </summary documentation for page objects /// <summary>Manages the UI interactions Samples with list, para, and references to properties /// <summary>A <see cref="MonitorGroup"/> device.</summary> /// <remarks>If not created with belonging new <see cref="Decoder"/> the properties for <see cref="MonitorGroup.Decoder"/> and <see cref="MonitorGroup.MonitorNumber"/> are <c>null</c>. /// <para>Refactoring necessary /// <list type="bullet"> /// <item><description>a MonitorGroup can connect to several decoders</description></item> /// <item><description>a MonitorGroup can be connected to several monitors.</description></item> /// </list> /// a MonitorGroup can connect to several decoders.</para> /// </remarks> /// <seealso cref="MonitorGroup" /> public class MonitorGroup : Device<MonitorGroup> References Links MSDN: Document your code with XML comments a list of all tags and their purpose and usage scenarios MSDN: XML documentation comments comprehensive description about the XML documentation comments see below node "Documentation tag reference" for descriptions about the individual nodes; eg Summary

wiki/issues/noticeable-problems.html.title: Noticeable Problems | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/issues/noticeable-problems.html.keywords: Noticeable Problems [[ TOC ]] Misleading naming the name of the UI elements doesn't fit to the usage hard to navigate through list of UI elements Sample: dialog "Add iSCSI Device" under pool Element Name Automation-ID Usage Network address tbUserName textbox for the user name iSCSI device type passord textbox for the password Name networkAdress textbox for the network address `` name textbox for the device name Sample: Configuration Pane for a Pool Element Name Automation-ID Usage Block reservation for downtime (days) cbLoadbalancingMode combobox for the recording preference NumericUpDown nuDistributionDuration reservation time for blocks Modal Window from Modal Window scanning for encoders starts a window with a progress bar the scanning stops by around 75% and a new modal dialog with scan-status appears this dialog has the progress window as the parent tried to get array of modal window from main window, but the new dialog is not listed inside instead it appears inside the array of modal windows from the scan window Missing consistency during device adding adding a VRM or VSG opens during adding such a dialog adding a Decoder needs these two dialogs This destroyed the smart initial approach to use the template method pattern to add monitor-like devices.

wiki/basics/dev-tree.html.title: Developer Tree | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/basics/dev-tree.html.keywords: Developer Tree [[ TOC ]] Folders at highest level Folder what's in & Intention .paket artifacts of our dependency management toolset named Paket cfg configuration items data sample data and data sets to play around (in case the data are important, consider to move to cfg ) doc documentation for the project, please read the section Documentation packages extracted packages and temporary artifacts from Paket (not included into repository) paket-files temporary artifacts from Paket (not included into repository) src the source or solution tree containing the source code Solution The src -folder (aka solution tree) is the developer`s main part of the project. It consists of these projects: DomainModel Contains the (UI-)Domain classes of the Configuration Client DomainModel.Tests Unit tests to test the DomainModel Utils Contains some helper classes and extensions. Utils.Tests Unit tests to test the helper classes and extensions. ConfigClient.Sdk This project could be treated as an internal SDK for test developers to interact with UI elements (abstracts the UI). ConfigClient.Sdk.Tests Unit tests for ConfigClient.Sdk ConfigClient.Api API for high level interaction with the Config Client to address use cases. ConfigClient.Api.Tests Unit tests to test the API correctness as well as the entry point for automatic Use Case tests in the context of complete workflows driving the API OpClient.Sdk This project could be treated as an internal SDK for test developers to interact with UI elements (abstracts the UI) of the Operation Client . OpClient.Sdk.Tests Unit tests for OpClient.Sdk OpClient.Api API for high level interaction with the Operation Client to address use cases. OpClient.Api.Tests Unit tests to test the API correctness as well as the entry point for automatic Use Case tests in the context of complete workflows driving the API Sdk.Commons Shared functionalities for the ConfigClient and OpClient projects at SDK level UseCaseTests Test to cover complete end to end use cases between Config Client and Operation Client ConfigClient.ExcelAdapter The ExcelAdapter is the bridge to configure the Config Client via an Excel sheet. ConfigClient.ConsoleApp The runner to instantiate the ExcelAdapter . AutomationElements Contains enhanced or new UI AutomationElements compared to the FlaUI project, for instance the Spinner control. The distinction between the SDK and the API is the level of abstraction. SDK abstracts the UI, API abstracts a use case. To add a device it is one call in the API ( Add Device ) but it needs different steps of the UI which are triggered via the SDK ( Activate Device Pane , Select the device type in tree , setup the device properties ). Documentation see also Documentation The doc -folder contains the project`s documentation. This documentation is built upon a Git sub-module to reference the project Wiki (sub-folder wiki ) artifacts to configure the DocFX documentation system and temporary output from it (sub-folders sdk , api sdk-api ) a Git sub-module with the static web-sites for the hosting platform (sub-folder _site )

wiki/guidelines/naming.html.title: Naming Guidelines | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/guidelines/naming.html.keywords: Naming Guidelines [[ TOC ]] Code structures Page Object how to name the classes and parts of it Branches naming the Git branches Images of the Wiki Code structures Waits & Timeouts Sporadically it is necessary to use long waits and timeouts, notably during the development period to understand some behaviors. Unfortunately, sometimes it is difficult to remove these waits later, because you cannot find them anymore. So help yourself and use a constant named LongWait to define the period (in TimeSpan, Seconds, whatever). Later it is easy to find all such occurrences by searching for this name. Page Object see also Pattern: Page Object Pattern page objects (aka page components/fragments) should consist of multiple files which contains the parts of a (partial) class one part should have the suffix ElementMap and must contain the access to UI elements as private protected properties [1] these properties must (or must not?) end with the UI element type (e.g. protected TextBox ServerNameTextBox ) Todo: clarify what better is (must or must not?) data input to page objects must follow the Fluent Interface design principle (must have for creational fashion!) data input must/should? be done via methods having the prefix Set to facilitate the fluent utilization ( fooDialog.SetPassword("p").SetUsername("u").SetPasswordShowing(false) ) Todo: clarify must/should [1] In the past we tried to use the private access modifier. But then we discovered situation where in derived classes we had the necessity to access the UI element of a parent class. One case was the check whether a dialog has finished to run some internal validation logic by using the Enabled property. e.g. if (OkButton.IsEnabled) { /* process next step */ } see also: Overview about typical used patterns: Page Object Pattern Organizing Partial Classes Branches default branches: develop common branch to share information; similar to Main in TFVC master we don't care now; but important in the future; don't use it yet individual/feature/realization branches follow this scheme [branch-type]/[user-identification]/[backlog-item-number]/[context] , where: branch type could be one of the following values: feat realize a backlog-item spike play around with new stuff, prototype new ideas dev under consideration; might be meaningful in case where we don't have a PBI which could be referenced user-identification is the prefix of the Bosch identifier (e.g. mue for Erika Mustermann [backlog-item-number] is the ID of that backlog item [context] short name of the backlog item to allow a easier understanding and avoid the necessity to dive into Azure DevOps Server to catch the topic/context Sample feat/mas/248691/replace-timespan addresses the task Replace TimeSpan.FromXyz(#) with #.Xyz() is realized from Stefan dev/apm/convert-to-tree-structure doesn't belong to a backlog item (e.g. for a "spontaneous" work package) Images of the Wiki maintain a folder named media at each folder level to allow an image access ala media/<image-name> put prefix onto the image name which references the wiki page using this image e.g. Architecture.foo.png for a picture which is used in the Architecture.md file this makes later restructuring much easier

wiki/architecture/introduction.html.title: Introduction | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/architecture/introduction.html.keywords: Introduction [[ TOC ]] Dependency Management some knowledge about dependency and package management Aspect Oriented Programming How the project is benefiting from AOP with PostSharp xUnit Knowledge around xUnit Dependency Management dependency management is done with Paket (on top of NuGet ) References BVMS.wiki: Dependency Management With Paket Google Docs Presentation: Paket Paket Project Google Docs Presentation: NuGet Hint: Google Docs Presentations are currently not accessible from E-Net, but from BCN. Aspect Oriented Programming we use PostSharp for AOP it allows us to target the anti-pattern "Primitive Obsession" elegant, e.g. for range limited types XUnit Categories, Trait To group unit test in a way which makes sense for a project, the Attribute Trait is used. The following example puts the test method Can_Start_App under the category UI-Basics . [Theory, Trait("Category", "UI-Basics")] [InlineData(false)] public void Can_Start_App(bool closeAppAfterRun) ReSharper 's Unit Test Explorer ( Extensions > ReSharper > Windows > Unit Tests or Ctrl + Alt + U ) shows the method then under category UI-Basics and belonging class: InlineData and MemberData xUnit allows the definition of multiple input values for a test. Such parametrizable tests needs to have the attribute Theory . Test without parameters are setup as Fact . With InlineData the parameters of the text method are filled with the corresponding data of the InlineData definition: [Theory] [InlineData("1.1.1.1", DecoderType.BarcoMonitorWall)] [InlineData("223.255.255.255", DecoderType.VideoJetDecoder7000)] public void Can_add_and_configure_decoder_device(string deviceName, DecoderType decoderType) With MemberData it is possible to extract the test-data provider for better readability: [Theory] [MemberData(nameof(Data))] public void Can_switch_Panes(PaneTypeWithPaneName paneTypeWithPaneName) { ... public static IEnumerable<object[]> Data => new List<object[]> { new object[] { new PaneTypeWithPaneName(...) }, new object[] { new PaneTypeWithPaneName(...) }, ...

wiki/patterns/page-object.html.title: Page Object Pattern | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/patterns/page-object.html.keywords: Page Object Pattern The access to the UI elements is abstracted via the Page Object Pattern . This is done for whole windows (e.g. the main application like ConfigClient ), for individual dialogs (e.g. to edit device properties) and for parts (e.g. the pane to configure a device). The following hierarchy gives an understanding about the contexts and scenarios in which to use: Return values of PageObject calls If the result of an interaction with a PageObject is another PageObject then this should be the result. As an example, for a dialog chain as used in wizards each click on the Next -button should return the PageObject for the following dialog and so on. At the end you can treat the click on the Finish -button to return the PageObject of the whole application, because this is the context for the next PageObject in this case. see also Main Classes | Generic Dialog Separation of Concerns for Page Objects To follow a the Single Responsibility Principle (see article "Page Object Pattern in Automated Testing") and allow an easier navigation & understanding we use partial classes to separate the diverse facets of the page object pattern. The suffix in the *.cs file name reflects the intention. So a source file which name contains ElementMap contains only the logic to interact with the UI elements which we like to access - mostly the logic to find the UI element in the parent UI container. See also Organizing Partial Classes to get an understanding how these partial classes parts are organized. Main class The main partial class is the class without any suffix. This class contains: the interface to the outside - all the public methods to interact with the Page Object additional internal logic to process interactions Sample: public partial class AddBrsDibosDialog : AddDeviceDialog<BrsDibos> { public AddBrsDibosDialog(Window parentWindow, AddBrsDibosDialogConfig config) : base(parentWindow, config) {} protected override string DeviceNameTextBoxAutomationId => "textBoxNetworkAddress"; protected override void AddDeviceCore() { var config = (AddBrsDibosDialogConfig)Config; NetworkAddressTextBox.Text = config.Address; UsernameTextBox.Text = config.Credentials.UserName; PasswordTextBox.Text = config.Credentials.Password; } } Since a while (End 2019) another principle was implemented - the provision of properties to interact with the PageObject in an abstract manner. These properties also contain the dependency logic to related properties. Using the setter of these properties ensures that depended properties are also getting the necessary values. In future versions it should be considered to extract this " PageObject interface" into a own class. Sample: The (partial class) NewUserGroupDialog contains a property which allows to get and set a name. public partial class NewUserGroupDialog : DialogBase { /// <summary>Gets or sets the name of the <see cref="UserGroup"/>.</summary> /// <value>The name of the <see cref="UserGroup"/>.</value> public string Name { get => NameTextBox.Text; set => NameTextBox.Text = value; } In the corresponding "mapping" partial class part ( *.ElementMap.cs ) the logic to find the NameTextBox is provided (see section ElementMap class ). public partial class NewUserGroupDialog { private TextBox NameTextBox => FindElement<TextBox>("userGroupNameTextBox"); Remark: In a more "command-based"-style the setter would be expressed with something like SetName(string name) . But because we also need a getter and the context itself is more like an essential feature/attribute/property of the class, the C# class property seems to be the best fitting construct. Remark: But the "command-based"-style is also used in other contexts - e.g. for clicking a button. Then the logic inside the ClickFooButton can also check whether the button is clickable/enabled and raise an exception if not. ElementMap class The *.ElementMap.cs class keeps all the logic to find and access the UI elements. Sample: public partial class AddBrsDibosDialog { private TextBox NetworkAddressTextBox => FindElement<TextBox>("textBoxNetworkAddress"); private TextBox UsernameTextBox => FindElement<TextBox>("textBoxUsername"); private TextBox PasswordTextBox => FindElement<TextBox>("textBoxPassword"); protected override Button OkButton => GetButtonByText("Scan"); } Summaries of the content behind the references (stated at the end of this section) Page Object: wraps all elements, actions and validations happening on a page in one single object There's an argument here that the name "page object" is misleading because it makes you think you should have just one page object per page. Something like "panel object" would be better - but the term "page object" is what's become accepted Model user behavior not user interfaces Think Page Components/Fragments, not Page Objects Keep business logic out of your Page Objects; a cleaner approach is to make Page Object classes responsible for doing a single job: locating elements on the page. Encapsulate interaction logic inside step methods, Keep step methods in action classes and use action classes to model user tasks Split into dedicated classes (SRP) Page Object Element Map: Contains all element properties and their location logic Page Object Validator: Consists of the validations that will be performed on the page Page Object (SearchEngineMainPage): Holds the actions that can be performed on the page like Search and Navigate. Exposes an easy access to the Page Validator through the Validate() method. The best implementations of the pattern hide the usage of the Element Map, wrapping it through all action methods UI Tests (SearchEngineTests): This class contains a group of tests related to the above page; it can hold only a single instance of the page object basic rule of thumb for a page object should allow a software client to do anything and see anything that a human can provide an interface that's easy to program to and hides the underlying widgetry in the window should encapsulate the mechanics required to find and manipulate the data in the gui control itself if you navigate to another page, the initial page object should return another page object for the new page (should return the a page object for the next page) Examples: to access a you should text field have accessor methods that take and return a string check box should use a boolean button represent it by an action oriented method names see also: Naming-Guideline for Page Objects Organizing Partial Classes References PluralSight course " Automating UI Tests for WPF Applications ", notably module "Building a Domain-specific Framework" and video "The architecture of the Domain-specific Framework" Page Objects that Suck Less  Tips for writing more maintainable Page Objects Page Object Pattern in Automated Testing PageObject Keep Your Page Objects DRY Advanced Page Object Pattern with Page Fragments Getting Started with Page Object Pattern

wiki/issues/bugs-and-fixes/config-client.title: Discovered issues in the Configuration Client and its fixes | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/issues/bugs-and-fixes/config-client.keywords: Discovered issues in the Configuration Client and its fixes Encoders without valid authentication There are encoders or decoders without valid authentication information (red lock). This can cause problems in later configuration tasks Do you want to continue? Affected encoders: testEncoder Solution give more time & put in method ConfigClientPageObject.SaveChanges() : Wait.UntilInputIsProcessed(2000.Milliseconds());

wiki/documentation/folder-structure.html.title: Folder structure | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/documentation/folder-structure.html.keywords: Folder structure The DevTree's doc -folder contains the project`s documentation itself and the configuration files for DocFX to process the content. The content and intention in detail: folder doc itself artifacts to configure the DocFX documentation system docfx-json the DocFX project file toc.yml the table of content file to hook up the wiki-pages index.md the landing page for the DocFX generated online documentation sub-folder wiki this is the repository of the Git sub-module from BVMS UI Automation project Wiki it was included via Gits submodule sub-command git submodule add git@ssh.dev.azure.com:v3/<organization>/<project>/<repository>.wiki doc/wiki sub-folder sdk contains the metadata for the SDK part of the documentation extracted from projects ConfigClient.DomainModel and ConfigClient.Sdk sub-folder api contains the metadata for the API part of the documentation extracted from projects ConfigClient.Api and ConfigClient.ConsoleApp sub-folder sdk-api artifacts to configure the DocFX documentation system merges content based on SDK and API metadata together sub-folder _site this is the repository of the Git sub-module with the static web-sites as an output of DocFX the repository is connected to the web site hosting platform (e.g. github.io as a remote) git submodule add git@<alias>:<username>/<username>.github.io.git doc/_site

wiki/concepts/dialog-usages.html.title: Usage of Dialog classes | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/concepts/dialog-usages.html.keywords: Usage of Dialog classes Overview DialogBase derived from WindowsPO (page object), which is a real window and not only a window part (aka page fragment, page component) abstract base class for dialogs with a confirmation and a cancellation option (usually via OK and Cancel buttons) provides an easy way to close the dialog via EndDialog(DialogCompletion dialogCompletion) where dialogCompletion indicates the way how to close (confirm or cancel) public virtual PageObject EndDialog(DialogCompletion dialogCompletion) SimpleDialog derived from DialogBase describes a very simple dialog which needs to get clicked away (Yes/No dialogs, OK-only dialogs) e.g. an informational dialog without any deeper meaning to respect for easy click away possibility two static methods are given ClickAway(Window parentWindow, string windowsTitle, TimeSpan timeout, DialogCompletion dialogCompletion) ClickAway(Window parentWindow, DialogCompletion dialogCompletion, Func<Button> findConfirmationButton, Func<Button> findCancelButton) GenericDialog<TConfirmationPo, TCancelPo> derived from DialogBase describes an abstract dialog with buttons to confirm or cancel the dialog ( OK , Cancel button) the generic type parameters TConfirmationPo and TCancelPo stand for the page objects which are returned as successors for confirmation and cancellation via delegates the behavior to return these succeeding page objects is managed the delegates can be set via constructor (recommended) GenericDialog(..., Func<TConfirmationPo> confirmationCommand, Func<TCancelPo> cancelCommand) via properties Func<TConfirmationPo> ConfirmationCommand { get; set; } ActivateConfigurationDialog<TConfirmationPo, TCancelPo> derived from GenericDialog<TConfirmationPo, TCancelPo> base class for ActivateExistingConfigurationDialog and ActivateNewConfigurationDialog contains additional logic to manage the UI control to force an activation and so on wait that the progress windows during activation disappears ActivateExistingConfigurationDialog binds the generic type parameters of base class to NullPageObject and ActivationManagerDialog ActivateNewConfigurationDialog binds the generic type parameters of base class to ConfigClientPageObject and ConfigClientPageObject contains additional logic to handle activation metadata (description, delayed activation, time to take active) Resources see also IFindWindowStrategy

wiki/guidelines/organizing-partial-class.title: Organizing Partial Classes | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/guidelines/organizing-partial-class.keywords: Organizing Partial Classes to bundle all belonging class parts ( <PageObject>.ElementMap.cs under one main node in the Solution Explorer we use the the tag <DependentUpon> in a *.csproj file the edit needs to be done manually with an editor like Notepad++ see also: Overview about typical used patterns: Page Object Pattern Naming-Guideline for Page Objects Sample for organizing partial classes In the follow sample AddVrmDialog.ElementMap.cs contains the ElementMap part of the AddVrmDialog class. This entry needs to get enhanced with the <DependentUpon> element referencing the "main" part of the class. the default entry: <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.cs" /> <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.ElementMap.cs" /> needs to get modified to: <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.cs" /> <Compile Include="Devices\Recorders\AddVrmDialog.ElementMap.cs"> <DependentUpon>AddVrmDialog.cs</DependentUpon> </Compile> Unfortunately this structuring is not refactoring-safe. After renaming a class it is necessary to rename the *.ElementMap.cs file as well and adjust the reference in the project file ( *.csproj ).

wiki/concepts/configuration-management.h.title: Configuration Management | BVMS UI Automation
wiki/concepts/configuration-management.h.keywords: Configuration Management The management of configurations is abstracted by the IConfigurationManager interface. It offers the following capabilities Save this triggers a click on Save Changes Button. ActivateConfiguration this activates the last saved configuration. RollbackLastConfiguration takes back the last configuration RollbackConfiguration takes back several configurations Revert and Rollbacks We have to distinct between these revert and rollback options Revert the working copy changes If the user saves a configuration without activating it, we name it revert the working copy changes Rollback the last configuration If we want to revert to throw away the last activated configuration. It doesn't matter whether there are unsaved working copy changed or not. In case there are some, they get also thrown away. Rollback to another configuration It should be possible to rollback to an individual entry of the activated configurations list. This is currently not supported and planned.
